org.smtlib

Class CharSequenceInfinite

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.smtlib.CharSequenceInfinite
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.CharSequence
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    CharSequenceReader, CharSequenceSocket

    public abstract class CharSequenceInfinite
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.CharSequence
    This class implements a CharSequence that obtains its characters from a source of characters of unknown length; it also provides some functionality to retain the characters and compute line numbers.

    The characters read are held in an internal char array, whose size grows as needed; it starts as initialSize and is expanded to currentSize*sizeMultiple + sizeIncrease whenever needed.

    The CharSequenceReader is an unconventional CharSequence in that its length() is not known; whether this will cause problems in some uses of the CharSequenceReader is unknown. The user should not use the value of length() directly; it seems to work in the ways it is called from Pattern.matcher.

    Author:
    David R. Cok

    • Constructor Detail

      • CharSequenceInfinite

        public CharSequenceInfinite(int initialSize,
                    int sizeIncrease,
                    double sizeMultiple)
        Constructor for a new instance
        Parameters:
        initialSize - the beginning size of the internal char array
        sizeIncrease - the amount to add to the current size of the internal char array when the array needs expanding
        sizeMultiple - the factor by which to multiply the current size of the internal char array when it needs expanding

    • Method Detail

      • charAt

        public char charAt(int index)
        Returns the char at the given index; this may block while input is read if the char has not been read before. An IOException that occurs while reading input is converted to an undeclared RuntimeException.
        Specified by:
        charAt in interface java.lang.CharSequence

      • readChars

        protected abstract boolean readChars()
                              throws java.io.IOException
        Reads more characters into the buffer; may block until some are read; returns false if end of input has been reached, in which case no additional chars should have been read. Does not expand the buffer, so the buffer must have extra space in it when readChars() is called.
        Returns:
        true if characters were read, false if no chars were read and end of input was reached
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • expandBuffer

        private void expandBuffer(int newSize)
        This expands the buffer to be at least as large as the argument; the buffer is expanded even if it is already of adequate size.
        Parameters:
        newSize - minimum size of the expanded buffer

      • length

        public int length()
        Returns the length of the CharSequence; for this implementation, the return value is at least as great as the unknown length of the CharSequence. The value is correct once the end of input has been reached.
        Specified by:
        length in interface java.lang.CharSequence
        Returns:
        the length of the CharSequence

      • subSequence

        public java.lang.CharSequence subSequence(int start,
                                 int end)
        Returns a subsequence of this CharSequence, of length end-start. CAUTION: This method can wrap a portion of the internal char array, but then the char array can be expanded, allocating a new char array - so just don't rely on changes to the sub-sequence to be reflected in the parent array.
        Specified by:
        subSequence in interface java.lang.CharSequence
        Parameters:
        start - the starting index of the subsequence
        end - one past the last character included in the subsequence
